newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX natgas ends down, then reacts little to AGAs.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX natgas ends down, then reacts little to AGAs.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures, pressured by reports of softer basis differentials at bidweek, ended lower on Wednesday in active trade, then reacted little to a weekly AGA stock build near the expected range.

June expired 1.7 cents lower at $2.346 per million British thermal units. July slipped 4.5 cents to close at $2.316, then traded on ACCESS between $2.29 and $2.315 after the AGA data. Other contracts ended down by 2.5 to 4.5 cents.
"It (the weekly AGA number) was right in the range. It's not a surprise either way," said one East Coast trader, noting June bidweek differentials softened today.

AGA said on Wednesday that U.S. gas stocks rose last week by 76 bcf, in line with expectations, and were still 212 bcf, or 24 percent, over year-ago levels. Eastern storage, which gained 47 bcf last week, remained 107 bcf, or 26 percent, above last year.
Injections need to average 10.5 bcf per day through October to hit 2.8 tcf ahead of the peak demand winter heating season.

Technical traders noted July held near-support Wednesday at $2.28 and closed over the $2.30 level. They pegged next support along the up trendline in the $2.24 area, with resistance seen at $2.37-2.38 and then at the contract high of $2.44.
Normal to slightly below-normal weather is expected to cover much of the East and Midwest into next week. The only heat forecast is for the Southwest.

In the May cash, Gulf Coast prices firmed a few cents Wednesday to the high-$2.20s, with June gas on the same pipes in the low-$2.30s. May Midcon gas gained a similar amount to the low-teens, with June in the mid-teens. New York city gate gas for May was steady to up slightly near the $2.50 level.
The NYMEX 12-month Henry Hub strip slid 3.5 cents to $2.321. NYMEX said 76,365 contracts traded, up from Tuesday's revised tally of 68,933.

On the KCBT, July finished six cents lower at $2.145, while deferreds ended down by four to eight cents. The July East/West spread widened by 1.5 cents to 17.1 cents (NYMEX premium). KCBT said 243 lots traded, down sharply from Tuesday's total of 1,417.
